newsitem.title: CHINA: CHINA CENTRAL BANKER RULES OUT INTEREST RATE CUT.
newsitem.headline: CHINA CENTRAL BANKER RULES OUT INTEREST RATE CUT.

text.p: China's central bank governor Dai Xianglong said on Thursday that current interest rate levels were appropriate and he saw no need for a change at present.
"Taking into consideration the interest of depositors... we believe the current rate is still appropriate," Dai, head of the People's Bank of China, told a news conference.
Current actual interest rates after taking account for inflation were about 4.0 percent, Dai said.
"This is about same or equal to Western countries," he said.
The central bank felt the current levels should be maintained, Dai said.
China's two interest rate cuts last year brought rates down by 2.48 percentage points on average, with the rate for one-year bank deposits now at 7.47 percent from 9.15 percent in May 1996.
Bank interest rates were now the lowest since 1990, analysts have said.
China's benchmark retail price inflation for January-July was 1.6 percent while consumer price inflation was 3.9 percent for the period.
